description:
Buceros rhinoceros silvestris, commonly known as the Sumatran Rhinoceros Hornbill, is a subspecies of the Rhinoceros Hornbill (Buceros rhinoceros) native to the tropical forests of Sumatra, Indonesia.

The Sumatran Rhinoceros Hornbill is a large, distinctive bird with a massive, curved beak and a prominent casque (helmet-like structure) on the top of its bill. Its plumage is predominantly black, with white patches on the wings and tail. This subspecies is slightly smaller than the nominate Rhinoceros Hornbill, with a body length of around 90-100 cm.

The Sumatran Rhinoceros Hornbill is an arboreal, frugivorous species, feeding primarily on figs and other fruits found in the dense canopy of the rainforest. It plays an important role in seed dispersal, contributing to the regeneration of the forest ecosystem.

Due to habitat loss and hunting, the Sumatran Rhinoceros Hornbill is classified as Endangered by the IUCN. Conservation efforts are focused on protecting and managing the remaining populations in Sumatra's protected areas, as well as addressing the threats of deforestation and poaching.
